Dear Yulonda Shell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/4/25, a staff member provided a youth with two edibles while
the youth was at school. When the youth returned, a nurse
checked on them and their heart rate was high
Investigation Interviews:
On 04/07/2025 a voicemail message was left for assigned FCW
advising of investigation and requesting a return call with any
additional information or concerns with placement. On 04/09/2025
contact was made face to face contact with Complainant. There
were no other concerns noted, and no additional information
provided.
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/07/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Youth A. She reported that Staff
1 provided her with a THC edible. She reported they were at the
onsite school and the staff person gave her a hug and put the
edible in her pocket. She described the edible as square, having
sugar on it and not being in a package. Youth A reported that she
asked Staff 1 to bring her the edible. Youth A also stated that this
was the first and only time she had made the request of Staff 1.
Youth A further advised that all staff bring in treats for residents at
the agency. She denied knowledge of staff bringing in THC
gummies for other residents. She reported that Youth B also gets
“stuff” from Staff 1. Youth A denied asking other staff to bring in
THC gummies for her.
Youth A also expressed concern that the agency does not meet
her needs for a high fiber diet. She stated that the agency
provides one Metamucil bar daily but denies that it is working for
her. She stated she is under the care of a GI doctor and is
diagnosed with Hirschsprung’s disease.
2

On 4/28/2025, Youth A was interviewed again. Youth A again
reported that she obtained the edibles from Staff 1. She denied
that she had changed her story or told youth or staff anything
different. She again reported being at school, giving Staff 1 a hug
and having the edibles slipped into her pocket. Youth A
specifically denied telling another resident that another staff, not
Staff 1, had provided the edibles. She also denied knowledge of
other occurrences of staff bringing in edibles. Youth A also
reported that she gets “stuff” from other residents. She refused to
identify which resident, but identified stuff as edibles, vapes and
weed pens. Youth A denied having any of the above mentioned
items in her possession or in her room at the time of the interview.
An interview was completed with Youth B. She advised that she
also attends school on campus. She denied being provided a
THC edible or any other drugs from staff. She reported that Youth
A told her and another youth that is no longer at the facility that a
staff brought her some THC gummies, but did not tell her the
staff’s name. Youth B stated it was not the first time Youth A told
her that. Youth B stated that youth at the agency do gummies all
the time but was unwilling to provide specific names. She denied
knowledge of any staff that brings in drugs for youth and denied
telling youth that staff brings her drugs or gummies.
An interview was completed with Compliance Staff. He confirmed
that the youth was not taken for a medical or sent for a drug
screen. He stated agency or parent consent is required for a drug
screen to be completed. He advised that the youth was seen by
the agency nurse and monitored because her heart rate was
elevated. A request was made for the incident report, medical
note and video footage from the school.
On 4/09/2025, Compliance Staff also provided confirmation that
Youth A is diagnosed with Hirschsprungs disease and is
encouraged to follow a special diet. He reported she is prescribed
a Metamucil fiber bar daily that she often refuses or gives to her
peers. He showed medical documentation confirming that it is
offered to youth daily.
Youth C was interviewed and advised that on Friday she
overheard Youth A talking to another staff. She was unable to
recall who the staff was, but heard Youth A say that Staff 1 had
brought her in a THC edible. She further reported hearing Youth
A say that she was going to get Staff 1 fired because Staff 1 was
involved in trying to get another staff at the agency fired. Youth C
shared that she believes Youth A is a liar and knows how to fake
3

things. She ended by saying she does not think the allegations
are true. Youth C stated that she told Staff 3 what she overheard
Youth A saying. Youth C denied hearing or knowing of other
instances of staff bringing in edibles or other drugs. She also
denied hearing youth, other than Youth A, say that staff bring in
edibles or other drugs.
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/09/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Staff 1. Staff 1 denied that
Youth A or any other resident has asked her to bring in edibles or
other drugs. She confirmed that Youth A was at the school when
she was there and that she saw her in the lunch line or lunch area
when she was working. She confirmed that Youth A gave her a
quick hug but denies that she put anything in her pocket. Staff 1
denies that she uses THC, other drugs or alcohol. She further
denied knowledge of other staff bringing in drugs or alcohol for
youth at the agency.
An interview was completed with Staff 3. She reported that Youth
A told her that Staff 1 gave her the THC edible. Staff 3 reported
that Youth A told her she was hallucinating and believed she could
fly. She confirmed that Youth A seemed to be under the
influence. Staff 3 reported she contacted the nurse, who treated
Youth A. Staff 3 recalled that Youth A was monitored and given
plenty of water. Staff 3 reported that Youth C told her that she
heard Youth A say that she was going to get Staff 1 fired because
Staff 1 is always trying to get DeRoy staff fired. Staff 3 denied that
she has ever brought in THC, drugs or Alcohol to youth at the
facility and denied knowledge of any staff bringing in items for
youth.
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/16/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Staff 2. She denied knowledge
of youth asking her to bring in THC edibles, other drugs or alcohol.
She also denied knowledge of any other staff bringing in these
items. She denied hearing Youth A request staff to bring in drugs
or alcohol. She recalled once hearing youth talk about staff
dropping off a package to them, but when she asked Youth A
about it she stated Youth A just started to laugh. Staff 2 denied
hearing the staff name that Youth A was referencing. Staff 2
4

confirmed that she has heard other youth and staff say that Youth
A uses drugs but does not have any proof. She also reported that
Youth A has been caught with a vape in the past but denied that it
was rumored or thought to have been provided by staff. Staff 2
denied being over at the school and does not know about anything
that occurred there. Staff 2 denied knowledge of any plan by
Youth A to get staff fired. On 04/28/2025, Staff 2 was interviewed
again. She reported she was not scheduled on 4/04/2025. She
denied interaction with Youth A, but did confirm that she has had
interaction with Youth D. She denied that Youth A or Youth D
have asked her to bring in edibles or drugs. She did confirm that
Youth D has asked her to bring a vape in before but denied that
she complied. She denied seeing youth with edibles at the
agency.
An interview was completed with Youth D. She reported that she
has asked Staff 1 to bring in drugs and alcohol. She reported that
she asked her about two months ago to bring in an edible and
Staff 1 responded “yes” but told her she could not tell anyone.
She reported Staff 1 brought them in and gave them to her in her
room. She also reported there was a second occasion that Staff 1
brought her edibles. Youth D did not have an exact date or time
frame for either occasion. She also reported that Youth A told her
that Staff 1 brought her in some edibles also about two months
ago. She denied that she or Youth A told staff. Youth D stated
she felt comfortable asking Staff 1 because Staff 1 tries to be cool
with the youth and talks about her personal life, going to the club
and having sex. Youth D denied that any other youth have heard
Staff 1 say these things, only her and Youth A. Youth D denied
any knowledge about Youth A getting edibles at school and
denied knowledge of other staff bringing in edibles or alcohol.
On 4/16/2025, Youth D was interviewed again. She denied that
Staff 4 ever brought in edibles for her and denied that she has
ever told that to any youth. On 4/28/2028, Youth D was
interviewed for the final time. She was advised she was being
interviewed again because it was reported that the story about
which staff brought in the edibles had changed. Youth D reported
that Youth A initially told her that Staff 1 provided her with the
edibles but then admitted that she lied, and that Staff 4 provided
them. Youth D denied recalling which staff she had told that she
lied to DHHS Staff. Youth D then reported that Staff 4 had
brought her in edibles sometime back in between December and
February. Youth D admitted that she had not reported this to me
and DHHS Specialist when she was previously interviewed. She
denied knowledge of any other staff brining in edibles or other
5

drugs. Youth D ended by reporting that Youth A told her that she
traded her meds with staff for Xanax. Youth D denied that she
had shared this information with any staff and denied that Youth A
told her who the staff person was. This allegation is being
investigated under Special Investigation #2025SIC0000620.
An interview was held with Youth E. She reported that Staff 4
brought in edibles for Youth A and Youth D. She reported she
was told this by Youth D. She denied that staff has brought in
edibles or other drugs for her.
An interview was completed with Youth F. She denied firsthand
knowledge of staff bringing in drugs or alcohol for youth. She did
report that she overheard staff and youth talking about that it was
reported that Staff 1 brought in edibles for Youth A and Youth D.
Youth F denied that Youth A or Youth D reported to her that Staff
1 brought in edibles for them. Youth F reported that Youth A often
lies a lot and would not believe what she is saying. Youth F
denied that she has asked staff to bring in any edibles, drugs or
alcohol and denied knowledge of any other youth asking staff to
do the same.
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/28/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Staff 4. Staff 4 confirmed that
she gave Youth A a hug while she was at school in the hallway
but denies giving Youth A edibles. She denied that Youth A has
asked her to bring in edibles, but stated Youth A has asked her to
bring in food. Staff 4 also denied that she has brought in edibles
or vape to Youth D. She denied knowledge of any staff bringing in
edibles or a vape to youth at the agency.
An interview was completed with Staff 5. She recalled that one
day after lunch, Youth A came out of the restroom looking tired.
Staff 5 reported that she brought Youth A from the school and
back to the building. She described Youth A as looking like “she
had something”. Staff 5 stated she remained with Youth A until
she got back to the building and denied that Youth A advised her
that she was “high”. She denied seeing Youth A interact with
other staff at the school. She reported she left Youth A at the
building with other agency staff but could not recall the name.
She recalled that when she returned to work the next day, she
“heard talk” about Youth A having taken an edible that she
received from staff. She was unable to recall what staff she heard
6

this information from. Staff 5 denied providing Youth A or any
other youth with edibles and denied seeing any youth at the
agency with edibles. She also denied any knowledge of staff
bringing in edibles, alcohol or other drugs for youth.
An interview was completed with Youth G. She reported that
Youth D was lying and not being honest during her interviews with
DHHS and DCWL. She reported that Youth D is trying to get staff
fired because they tell her no and don’t do what she says. Youth
G reported that Youth A has been “bugging” staff to buy her a
vape and they have said no. Youth G was unable to provide
names of specific staff that she is aware that Youth A has
requested this of. Youth G denied that staff has brought her any
edibles or other drugs and denied knowledge of staff bring in
edibles or other drugs.
On 04/29/2025 a DHHS Closing Case Conference was held. A
review of the case investigation was completed. DCWL provided
preliminary findings of investigations. Final confirmation of no
DHHS Findings was confirmed on 5/15/2025.
Documentation Reviewed:
Vista Maria Agency Policy – Drug/Alcohol-Free Workplace
Policy: Employees are prohibited from the use, sale, dispensing,
distribution, possession, or manufacture of illegal drugs, controlled
substances, narcotics, or alcoholic beverages or other substances
that might affect employee performance on Vista Maria’s work
sites.
Vista Maria Incident Report – Incident date: 04/23/2025
Narrative: At the above date and time Youth D informed agency
staff that she was getting edible from Staff 4 and she stated she
also lied to DHHS about who was giving her and Youth A edibles.
Vista Maria Incident Report – Incident date: 04/04/2025
Narrative: Youth A asked to speak with Staff 3 and advised that
Staff 1 had provided her a THC edible. Staff 3 requested the
agency nurse and informed supervision on staff.
Vista Maria Video Footage – Video Footage is dated for
4/4/2025. It shows video footage of Youth A and Staff 1 walking
together in the hallway. The video skips for about 25 seconds and
when it returns to focus Youth A is walking back into her
classroom and Staff 1 is sitting in a chair. In what was able to be
viewed close interaction or hugging of Youth A and Staff 1 or of
Youth A and any other staff was not observed.
7

Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found in
compliance with the licensing rule. Both youth and staff were
interviewed and there was not sufficient evidence to confirm a
violation. Staff denied engaging in inappropriate activity and the
reported stories of the youth interviewed were inconsistent and
lacked the ability to have them confirmed.
Technical Assistance
It is recommended that if a youth alleges someone provided them
drugs, or they had access to drugs, that a drug test be conducted.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: ©
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency staff provides food and snacks to residents without
supervisor permission.
Investigation Interviews:
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/07/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Youth A. Youth A reported that
Staff 1 would bring in food/treats and order food for her via Door
Dash. Youth A stated that Staff 1 would also sometimes do the
same for other residents but was unable to provide specific
names.
An interview was completed with Youth B. Youth B reported that
staff will share one or two chips with youth at the agency, but don’t
really bring in full snacks for them because they will have to share
with everyone.
8

Youth C was interviewed and denied knowledge of staff bringing
in treats or food for specific residents.
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/09/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Staff 1. She denied bringing
food in for youth or sharing any of her personal food with youth at
the agency. She denied knowledge of other staff bringing in food
or snacks for youth and denied that staff door dash food to the
agency for youth.
An interview was completed with Staff 3. Staff 3 confirmed that
she has shared or given youth at the facility food or snacks.
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/16/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Staff 2. Staff 2 confirmed that
youth are always asking staff to bring in food or asking for some of
their food. She confirmed that she has provided youth candy or
shared some of her snacks with the youth.
An interview was completed with Youth D. She reported that staff
bring in food all the time for specific youth. She stated that “all the
staff do it”.
An interview was held with Youth E. She reported that staff
provide food and snacks to youth that they bring from home.
Youth D reported that staff brings in food and snacks for youth at
the agency. She denied that items are brought in for everyone all
the time.
An interview was completed with Youth F. She denied seeing
staff bring in food or snacks from outside of the agency to youth.
The following interviews were completed at Vista Maria on
04/28/2025 along with DHHS Specialist unless otherwise
indicated.
An interview was completed with Staff 4. She confirmed she has
provided candy and snacks to youth at the agency without
providing it to all youth or obtaining supervisor permission. She
stated, “everybody brings in snacks/treats for the residents”.
9

An interview was completed with Staff 5. Staff 5 denied bringing
in food or snacks for youth without supervisor permission.
Documentation Reviewed:
Vista Maria Agency Policy - Staff and Client Interaction Policy
Never accept purchased or monetary gifts/items from clients. All
gifts/items for clients will be provided via the Vista Boutique or
purchased with authorized Vista Maria funds. Any exceptions to
the above must be approved by the Building Manager.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with the licensing rule. Both staff and youth
were interviewed, and it was confirmed that agency staff were
providing food and snacks to Vista Maria youth without
supervisory permission and without providing it to all youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
